awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: NSF NeTS PI Meeting - Spring 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will organize a virtual PI meeting for the NeTS community, with a broad invitation provided to current PIs, eminent researchers in academia, aspiring PIs, early-career faculty and researchers from diverse backgrounds. The PI meeting will include sessions on future networking research challenges, early career advice and NSF programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
This goal of this project was to organize a virtual PI meeting for the NeTS community, with a broad invitation provided to current PIs, eminent researchers in academia, aspiring PIs, early-career faculty and researchers from diverse backgrounds. The PI meeting included sessions on future networking research challenges, early career advice and NSF programs.

Specically, the NeTS NSF virtual PI meeting was conducted on Feb 23-24 with 107 participants on day-1 and 96 on day-2. The event included two keynote speakers:

  1. Prof. Jim Kurose (UMass Amherst) who spoke on "Networking Research and Education -- Macrotrends;" and
  2. Prof. Margaret Martonosi (NSF CISE) who spoke on "The Computer and Information Science and Engineering Landscape -- A Look Forward."

The event also included a panel on "The Future of Networks" with Dr. Ranveer Chandra (Microsoft Research), Prof. Don Towsley (UMass Amherst), Prof. Minlan Yu (Harvard University) and Prof. Xia Zhou (Columbia University).

The event included representation from all areas of CISE. A series of breakouts were held to brainstorm future topics of relevance to CISE and NeTS in particular. The topics discussed included Quantum Networking, Software-Defined and Programmable Networks, Sharing Best Practices: On Writing a Good NeTS Proposal, Machine Learning and Networking, Next-Generation Wireless,  Backscatter Communication and Low-Power Wireless,  Network Security, Privacy and Resilience, Space and Airborne Networking,  Mobile Health and Networking for Medical Environments, Network Design for Future Telepresence Applications AR/VR/XR, IoT in New Domains, Cloud Networking \& Data Centers, Network Measurement and Analysis, Broadening Participation in Computing -- NeTS Perspectives, Reconfigurable Surfaces and Meta Materials for Mobile Systems, Future Networking Curriculum, and Energy Consumption \& Sustainability.

The event included a jointly formulated report on recommendations to the NSF that was delivered to the NSF at the end of the event. 

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Mosharaf Chowdhury
